# About This Lab
**Objective:** In this lab, you will use Zeppelin to work with DataFrames.
Begin by learning about Apache Spark documentation and JavaDocs. Read and
display a JSON file into a DataFrame. Query the DataFrame.
**File locations:** 
    Data (local): /data/custom/voyager-episodes.json
**Successful outcome:**
**Before you begin:**
**Related lessons:** Apache Spark Basics

msg.data: Setup

paragraphs.title: Environment variable required to use SetJobGroup
paragraphs.text:
%sh

PYSPARK_PIN_THREAD=true

%md
SetJobGroup
By default a unit of Spark execution is indendent of all others. On a cluster where you have 
multiple Spark actions or jobs this is makes it difficult to follow the application. 
Application programmers can use this method to group all of those actions and jobs
together. This gives a group description. Once set, the Spark web UI will associate
such jobs with this group.

%md
In a Zeppelin notebook the Spark shell is started by the Livy interpreter. You will not start the Spark shell manually.
From a command line you will have to start the Spark shell with either `spark-shell` or `pyspark`.

Spark creates a SparkSession object called spark. The command `spark` will display information about the spark object. 
This is displaying the memory address.

msg.data: Lab

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Overview the Apache Spark Documentation

1. View the Spark documentation in your web browser by visiting [http://spark.apache.org/docs/2.4.0/](http://spark.apache.org/docs/2.4.0/).
2. From the Programming Guides menu, select SQL, DataFrames, and Datasets. Briefly review the guide and bookmark the page for later reference.
3. From the API Docs menu, select either Scala or Python, depending on your language preference. Bookmark the API page for use during class. Later exercises will refer to this documentation.
4. If you are viewing the Scala API, notice that the package names are displayed on the left. Use the search box or scroll down to find the org.apache.spark.sql package. This package contains most of the classes and objects you will be working with in this course. In particular, note the Dataset class. Although this exercise focuses on DataFrames, remember that DataFrames are simply an alias for Datasets of Row objects. So all the DataFrame operations you will practice using in this exercise are documented on the Dataset class.
5. If you are viewing the Python API, locate the pyspark.sql module. This module contains most of the classes you will be working with in this course. At the top are some of the key classes in the module. View the API for the DataFrame class; these are the operations you will practice using in this exercise.

paragraphs.text: %livy.pyspark

%md
Spark has not yet read the data in the file, but it has scanned the file to infer the schema. View the schema, and note that the column names match the record field names in the JSON file.

msg.data: Spark has not yet read the data in the file, but it has scanned the file to infer the schema. View the schema, and note that the column names match the record field names in the JSON file.

paragraphs.title: 4 - Print the schema of the new dataframe
paragraphs.text: %livy.pyspark

%md
Display the data in the DataFrame using the show function. If you don’t pass an argument to show, Spark will display the first 20 rows in the DataFrame. 
For this step, display the first five rows. Note that the data is displayed in tabular form, using the column names defined in the schema.

msg.data:
Display the data in the DataFrame using the show function. If you don’t pass an argument to show, Spark will display the first 20 rows in the DataFrame.
For this step, display the first five rows. Note that the data is displayed in tabular form, using the column names defined in the schema.

paragraphs.title: 5 - Display the data of the new dataframe
paragraphs.text: %livy.pyspark

%md
The show and printSchema operations are actions—that is, they return a value from the distributed DataFrame to the Spark driver. 
Both functions display the data in a nicely formatted table. 
These functions are intended for interactive use in the shell, but do not allow you actually work with the data that is returned. 
Try using the take action instead, which returns an array (Scala) or list (Python) of Row objects. You can display the data by iterating through the collection.

msg.data:
The show and printSchema operations are actions—that is, they return a value from the distributed DataFrame to the Spark driver.
Both functions display the data in a nicely formatted table.
These functions are intended for interactive use in the shell, but do not allow you actually work with the data that is returned.
Try using the take action instead, which returns an array (Scala) or list (Python) of Row objects. You can display the data by iterating through the collection.

### Query a Dataframe

msg.data: Query a Dataframe

paragraphs.title: 7 - Count the rows of the dataframe
paragraphs.text: %livy.pyspark

%md
##### select
DataFrame transformations typically return another DataFrame. Try using a select transformation to return a DataFrame with only the id, season, number, airdate, and name columns, then display its schema. Note that only the selected columns are in the schema.

msg.data:
select

DataFrame transformations typically return another DataFrame. Try using a select transformation to return a DataFrame with only the id, season, number, airdate, and name columns, then display its schema. Note that only the selected columns are in the schema.

paragraphs.title: 8 - Create a dataframe with only the id, season, number, airdate, and name columns
paragraphs.text: %livypyspark

%md
A query is a series of one or more transformations followed by an action. Spark does not execute the query until you call the action operation. Display the first rows of the new dataframe.

msg.data: A query is a series of one or more transformations followed by an action. Spark does not execute the query until you call the action operation. Display the first rows of the new dataframe.

paragraphs.title: 9 - View the content of this new dataframe
paragraphs.text: %livy.pyspark

%md
The power of Functional Programing is transformations in a query can be chained together. Execute a single 
command to show the results of a query using select and where. The resulting DataFrame will contain only the 
columns `season`, `number`, `name`, and `airdate`, and only the rows where the season is `4`.

columns season, number, name, and airdate, and only the rows where the season is 4.

Spark uses a construct of lazy program, meaning data is not manipulated until there is a call for an action.

View the schema, and note that the column names match the record field names in the JSON file.

is the DataFrame.

paragraphs.text:
%md
The `show` and `printSchema` operations are actions—that is, they return a value from the distributed DataFrame 
to the Spark driver. Both functions display the data in a nicely formatted table. These functions are intended 
for interactive use in the shell, but do not allow you to actually work with the data that is returned. 

To work with the data try using the action `take` function instead. The `take` function returns an array (Scala) 
or list (Python) of Row objects. Use Python foreach loop syntax to display the data by iterating through the collection.

msg.data:
The show and printSchema operations are actions—that is, they return a value from the distributed DataFrame
to the Spark driver. Both functions display the data in a nicely formatted table. These functions are intended
for interactive use in the shell, but do not allow you to actually work with the data that is returned.

To work with the data try using the action take function instead. The take function returns an array (Scala)
or list (Python) of Row objects. Use Python foreach loop syntax to display the data by iterating through the collection.

The output is the actual raw record from the dataset, identified as a Row. Following JSON file format 
each field is assigned a field name. The "u" identifes the data as UTF formated text. This is coming
from Python not Spark.

DataFrame transformations typically return another DataFrame. Try using a `select` transformation 
to return a DataFrame with only the `make` and `model` columns, then display its schema. Note that 
only the selected columns are in the schema.

only the selected columns are in the schema.

paragraphs.title: 9 - View the content of this new dataframe
paragraphs.text:
%livy.pyspark

sc.setJobGroup("Exploring DataFrames","Show only  id, season, number, airdate, and name")
epSmallDF.show()

paragraphs.text:
%md
Remember Spark is lazy. A query is a series of one or more transformations followed by an action. 
Spark does not execute the query until you call the action operation. Display the first rows of the 
new dataframe. Use the Spark DataFrame `show` function.

msg.data:
Remember Spark is lazy. A query is a series of one or more transformations followed by an action.
Spark does not execute the query until you call the action operation. Display the first rows of the
new dataframe. Use the Spark DataFrame show function.

paragraphs.title: 10 - Chain several transformations and an action
paragraphs.text:
%livy.pyspark

sc.setJobGroup("Exploring DataFrames","Chain the transformations and an action")
voyEpDF.select("season", "number", "name", "airdate").where("season = 4").show()

paragraphs.text:
%md
The power of Functional Programing is transformations in a query can be chained together. Execute a single 
command to show the results of a query using select and where. The resulting DataFrame will contain only the 
columns `season`, `number`, `name`, and `airdate`, and only the rows where the season is `4`.

msg.data:
The power of Functional Programing is transformations in a query can be chained together. Execute a single
command to show the results of a query using select and where. The resulting DataFrame will contain only the
columns season, number, name, and airdate, and only the rows where the season is 4.
